newsitem.title: JAPAN: No big Japan portfolio change seen after euro--MOF.
newsitem.headline: No big Japan portfolio change seen after euro--MOF.

text.p: Japan's Finance Ministry does not expect Japanese institutional investors to heavily reshuffle their portfolios ahead of the introduction of a single European currency in 1999, Vice Finance Minister Takatoshi Kato said on Tuesday.

Kato told a Tokyo symposium on European economic and monetary union (EMU) that Japanese institutional investors would consider boosting euro-denominated assets if the euro market were to develop in depth and to rise in liquidity.
"But much depends on how and when EMU participants decide on a conversion rate for each European currency against the euro and how they erase uncertainties surrounding the single currency," he said.
About 20 percent of Japan's private sector firms' investment in foreign bonds is denominated in European currencies, he said.
Japan wants to diversify the currencies it keeps as its external reserves, as a large portion of its reserves is currently denominated in U.S. dollars, he said.
"In this regard, Japan will welcome the development and success of the euro," Kato said.
Kato also said he does not expect the introduction of the euro to fundamentally change the current link between many Asian currencies and the dollar.
"However, preference for the euro as a financial asset is likely to grow in neighbouring Asian countries as well as in Japan if the euro succeeds in gaining international confidence," he said.
"It is necessary to avoid financial market confusion that can be caused by the introduction of a single European currency," he added.
The EMU settlement system should also be open to countries outside of the EMU, he said.
